question: What are the potential legal and political consequences, both immediate and long-term, of Texas officials seeking arrests and court rulings to declare vacant the seats of Democratic lawmakers who left the state to break quorum?

content.source_1:
Legal experts say it‚Äôs ‚Äúinconsistent with the Texas Constitution‚Äù to argue that leaving the state to halt legislative action qualifies as abandoning an office.

Sign up for The Brief, The Texas Tribune‚Äôs daily newsletter that keeps readers up to speed on the most essential Texas news.

Gov.Greg Abbotton Tuesdayasked the Texas Supreme Courtto remove Houston Rep.Gene Wu, chair of the House Democratic Caucus, from office, an unprecedented escalation in Republicans‚Äô efforts to resume business in the Legislature and advance new congressional maps.

At least 50 House Democrats have left the state to prevent the chamber from obtaining a quorum ‚Äî the minimum number of members necessary to undertake legislative business ‚Äî in an effort to delay the passage of new congressional lines that could net five more seats for Republicans. The unusual mid-decade redistricting effort comes at the behest of President Donald Trump and his political team, despiteinitial reluctancefrom Abbott and the majority of Texas‚Äô GOP congressional delegation.

Democrats left the state Sunday afternoon, ahead of a Monday vote to advance the bill. Wu, as leader of the House Democrats, announced that ‚Äúthis corrupt special session is over‚Äù and vowed to stay out of the state long enough to allow the session's remaining two weeks to run out.

In his legal filing, Abbott argued that amounts to an abandonment of office and is sufficient grounds to have Wu‚Äôs seat vacated.

‚ÄúWhat is at stake here? Nothing less than the future of Texas,‚Äù Abbott wrote. ‚ÄúIf a small fraction of recalcitrant lawmakers choose to run out the clock today, they can do so for any, and every, Regular or Special Session, potentially bankrupting the State in an attempt to get their way.‚Äù

In a response filed with the court Friday, Wu said he had not abandoned his office and argued the entire lawsuit against him should be thrown out.

‚ÄúTo the contrary, he continues to carry out his legislative duties as his judgment dictates,‚Äù lawyers for Wu wrote in the filing. In asking for the case to be dismissed, they noted that Wu had not died, nor had he been expelled by the House by a two-thirds vote or voluntarily resigned ‚Äî all of which would be grounds for removal from office under state law.

Attorney GeneralKen Paxton, who threatened to file similar legal actions earlier in the day against multiple House Democrats, followed Abbott's emergency petition by sending his own letter to the state Supreme Court hours later, in which he argued that Abbott lacked the authority to request the removal.

Paxton wrote that while he "appreciates the Governor‚Äôs passion" for restoring a quorum, state law permits only the attorney general or a local county or district attorney to bring what's known asa quo warranto proceeding, which seeks a member's removal on the grounds that they have abandoned their office.

In the letter, Paxton said he would take action against the absent legislators if the House continued to lack a quorum on Friday, the deadline set by House SpeakerDustin Burrows. He followed through on the threat,asking the Supreme CourtFriday afternoon to expel 13 Democrats from the chamber while echoing Abbott's argument that the lawmakers had effectively abandoned their offices.

Abbott later clarified in asocial media postthat his filing sought quo warranto through a provision in the Texas Constitution and a separate portion of government code, which he said would give his office the proper authority. He also attached a letter addressed to the state Supreme Court in the post that stated "at least 500 years of common law" made it clear the governor's office could make the filing.

Paxton previously acknowledged that this would likely be a lengthy and complicated process, telling conservative podcaster Benny Johnson that his office would have to bring individual lawsuits in each member's district. But in Friday‚Äôs filing, he argued that the Texas Supreme Court has the right to rule directly on the matter, especially when there is a need to swiftly resolve the situation.

If a judge were to find that the seats were vacant, they would be filled through a special election.

The Supreme Court of Texas is entirely Republican, and Chief Justice Jimmy Blacklock,appointed in January, was formerly Abbott‚Äôs general counsel. When he appointed Blacklock to the bench in 2018,Abbott saidhe ‚Äúwanted to make sure that the person I appointed was going to make decisions that I know how they are going to decide.‚Äù Blacklock has said that was more a reflection of their shared judicial philosophy.

In 2021, Blacklockauthored an opinionfor the court that said the Texas Constitution enables the possibility of a so-called ‚Äúquorum break,‚Äù although it also allows for consequences to bring members back.

Legal experts say it would be difficult to argue that engaging in a quorum break qualifies as abandonment of office.

‚ÄúI am aware of absolutely no authority that says breaking quorum is the same as the intent to abandon a seat,‚Äù said Charles ‚ÄúRocky‚Äù Rhodes, a constitutional law expert at the University of Missouri law school. ‚ÄúThat would require the courts extending the premise to the breaking point. It‚Äôs inconsistent with the very text of the Texas Constitution.‚Äù

Chad Dunn, a former attorney for the Texas Democratic Party who is now representing Wu, said proving abandonment of office would require showing that the member had failed to perform the duty of their office and intended to relinquish the seat, both of which he argues are not evident in a quorum break.

‚ÄúIt is not just an option, but one of the features of elected office to decide whether to appear and help establish quorum,‚Äù Dunn said, speaking generally about state law before the case was filed. ‚ÄúEach member as part of their duty of office must make that decision.‚Äù

In the filing, Abbott disagreed, reiterating the idea that leaving to deny the House the votes it needs to proceed is tantamount to relinquishing the office.

‚ÄúIt is no answer for Wu to say that he plans to continue serving as a representative,‚Äù Abbott wrote. ‚ÄúHis own statements and actions show a refusal to actually serve as a representative in fact. That‚Äôs because what representatives do is represent their constituents in the legislative chamber. They appear for a quorum. They meet with other legislators in hearings. They speak with their constituents. They debate bills. And, in the end, they vote their district.‚Äù

Dunn condemned the lawsuit in Friday‚Äôs response, saying that the Supreme Court was not the proper venue, the governor was not the proper litigant and the entire suit is based on hearsay and speculation.

‚ÄúGiven that the Governor has included no proper statement of facts or record to respond to ‚Äî itself a grave due process problem ‚Äî Respondent generally disputes the factual allegations that are scattered throughout the petition, such as they are,‚Äù the filing says.

Texas is among several states planning to redraw congressional maps ahead of the 2026 midterm elections. Other states that could initiate redistricting include Ohio, New York and California,Newsweekpreviously reported.

Republicans hold a slim majority in the House of Representatives, with 219 seats compared to the Democrats' 212. There are currently four vacancies.

Texas Republican state lawmakers unveiled the first draft of a new congressional map last week. Under the new map, the Lone Star State's four Democratic-leaning major metropolitan areas would be divided among at least four congressional districts apiece.

Nearly all of the redrawn districts would have a Republican majority, according to the Associated Press.

Republicans hold 25 of the state's 38 seats in the House, and the new map could raise the total seats won in the 2026 midterms to 30 if passed.

"We are entitled to five more seats," President Donald Trump said Tuesday in a CNBC interview.

On Sunday,Texas House Democratsannounced they will breaking quorum to prevent a vote on the new map.

In the Texas House of Representatives, two-thirds of its 150 members must be present to reach a quorum. Without a quorum, "no business shall be transacted, except to compel the attendance of absent members or to adjourn," according to the Texas House Rules of Procedure.

During Tuesday's session of the Texas House, 54 Democrats broke quorum,KXANreported, two fewer than on Monday.

Representatives Philip Cortez and Eddie Morales were not present on Monday, but returned to the House on Tuesday.

The term "gerrymandering" dates to 1812, when then-Massachusetts Governor Elbridge Gerry signed a bill redrawing state Senate districts to benefit the Democratic-Republican Party. A newspaper illustration called one district "The Gerry-mander," due to its resemblance to a salamander.

The term later evolved to describe any district drawn for political advantage.

The Democrats who were not present on Tuesday were given until Friday to appear before the House before facing legal action.

Republican Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton said Monday on Fox Business‚Äô ‚ÄúThe Bottom Line‚Äù that Democrats fleeing the state to avoid a vote on redistricting will face consequences either from the state House or from the state‚Äôs Supreme Court.

Reportsof Democrats fleeing Texas for blue states like Illinois in hopes of blocking a vote on the proposed redistricting map broke Sunday evening. Paxton said he favors arresting Democrat lawmakers who fled. He was asked how he would handle each individual lawmaker.(RELATED: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs A Bad Look‚Äô: Chuck Todd Blasts Texas Dems For Protesting Gerrymandering By Fleeing To Gerrymandered Illinois)

‚ÄúSo the Speaker sets the consequences. So he can find them. He can have other consequences inside of the House as far as committee assignments and what they end up getting to do inside the House. That typically does not happen. This has happened in Texas history when I was in the House,‚Äù Paxton said.

‚ÄúTypically what we‚Äôve done is we have the governors, the Republican governors, have just kept calling special sessions because, ultimately, these people don‚Äôt want to typically live in the state they‚Äôve gone to. And they ultimately come back, and they‚Äôre forced to vote. So that‚Äôs been typical,‚Äù Paxton added. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre looking at other options. If we can‚Äôt arrest them, we want to have the opportunity to potentially take them out of office, at least force them back in for a court hearing.‚Äù

In response to the 51 Democrats leaving for Illinois, Paxtontookto X on Sunday, saying he supports the ‚Äúimmediate arrest of these rogue lawmakers who‚Äôve fled their duties.‚Äù

‚ÄúThese radical Democrats are spitting in the face of every Texan they swore to represent. This is cowardice and dereliction of duty, and they should face the full force of the law without apology,‚Äù Paxton wrote.

By Monday, the Texas Housepasseda motion to issue arrestwarrantsfor the lawmakers who fled following their failure to appear at the chamber to vote on redistricting the state‚Äôs congressional maps.

The Fox Business guest host said the court hearings ‚Äúare really crucial‚Äù due to taking place in ‚Äúcertain districts that are not favorable to the governor‚Äôs cause of redistricting.‚Äù While there was potential for an outcome unfavorable to Republicans, Paxton addressed how he saw the rulings playing out.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs true. I mean, we will be in Democratic districts. However, this is a state issue. So, ultimately, this case will likely go to the Texas Supreme Court, which isn‚Äôt necessarily unfavorable,‚Äù Paxton said.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre a strong Republican body that tends to follow the Constitution and follows the law,‚Äù Paxton said. ‚ÄúSo I‚Äôm confident that when they get this case, they‚Äôll make an appropriate and good ruling.‚Äù

Accordingto the Texas Tribune, the motion passed by the state‚Äôs House will not have the absent Democrat members face civil or criminal charges, as the warrant only applies within Texas state lines.
